body_html:
Integer arguments alone don't mean that there is not a GPU kernel, but there tend to be far more GPU kernels for float types than integer types.

Bincount seems to not have any GPU support -- only CPU. Unfortunately there's no good way to know this from the documentation. The best bet is to look in the source code. If you look in this directory and search for the op you're using:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/core/kernels

You can read the source. Scroll all the way to the bottom to find the "registration" macros. If you don't see a line that looks like REGISTER_BLAH_GPU(float32) or TF_CALL_float32(REGISTER_GPU) ... basically some line mentioning the type you care about and the word "GPU" then it probably means there's no GPU registration for that type/op combination.

body:
Integer arguments alone don't mean that there is not a GPU kernel, but there tend to be far more GPU kernels for float types than integer types.

Bincount seems to not have any GPU support -- only CPU. Unfortunately there's no good way to know this from the documentation. The best bet is to look in the source code. If you look in this directory and search for the op you're using:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/core/kernels

You can read the source. Scroll all the way to the bottom to find the "registration" macros. If you don't see a line that looks like `REGISTER_BLAH_GPU(float32)` or `TF_CALL_float32(REGISTER_GPU)` ... basically some line mentioning the type you care about and the word "GPU" then it probably means there's no GPU registration for that type/op combination.
